Nithin Hassan, 41, has always been fascinated with building something of his own.

As a child in India, he would get in trouble for dismantling electronics around the house just so he could peek inside.

In college, in true startup fashion, he started working on a small business out of his parent's garage in Bengaluru, assembling computers for friends and family.

It was the early 2000s and the internet was not the trove of knowledge it is today — Hassan was relying on books to learn. Finding mentorship and the right guidance was a challenge, too.

Advertisement

Everyone around Hassan told him that going to the US for a master's degree was the next big opportunity. So he did.

Over the next 16 years, he put his startup plans on hold and worked at some of the world's biggest companies, including Amazon, Microsoft, and Meta.

Nithin Hassan lived in the US for 15 years before returning to India last year. Nithin Hassan

But the pandemic felt like a turning point. And its aftermath made India look like a lab-designed business environment: It had just become the world's most populous country, the pandemic had created pent-up demand for consumer products, and growing internet adoption made commerce more scalable, he said.

So Hassan left behind about $500,000 in annual pay at Meta to move back to Bengaluru in December 2023 with his wife and two children. He has since launched two startups.

Advertisement

Hassan is part of a group of expat Indians moving back home to venture out on their own. As such, he's also part of a decades-long trend of reverse migration back to India.

The trend began in the 1990s and picked up at the turn of the century, driven by the economic collapse in 2008, said Binod Khadria, the president of Global Research Forum on Diaspora and Transnationalism. Many of those who returned to India for work were largely working for multinational companies.

Today, the impetus for the move often looks a bit different: It's driven by factors like unstable visa policies and economic recessions, which lead to uncertainty when it comes to jobs and duration of stay in these destinations.

Many returnees find work in tech, but the finance, retail, and climate sectors also absorb a large number of expat Indians, Khadia said. And some of the returnees are heading back to India to start companies of their own.

Advertisement

India is undergoing a startup explosion. The country reported over 140,800 recognized startups at the end of June — nearly 50,000 more than last year — and credited them with creating 1.6 million direct jobs.

To be sure, not all of these companies will make it big — and some do still stumble, like Oyo and Byju's. But the chaos, where even established startups are trying and failing, makes India a fair playing field for new entrants, Hassan said.

Business Insider spoke to six first-time founders about why they have recently returned to India after spending several years, or even an adult life, abroad.

Fastest-growing economy

The health of the economy and interest from investors are fueling the entrepreneurship boom.

Advertisement

India's economic growth in 2023 — 8.2% — was the fastest of all large economies worldwide. That's led to greater purchasing power, which lets companies, including startups, sell more.

India's inflation rate of about 3.5% is well below its annual wage growth of 9.6%. This makes inflation less of a challenge than it is for slower-growing peers, where consumer-focused businesses have been hurt by high prices.

Related stories

Investors are getting in on the action.

From 2015 to 2021, the number of unique investors in India nearly quadrupled, though the number is tracking much lower this year, per PitchBook.

Advertisement

"Other than a slight downturn in 2022 and 2023 due to global macroeconomic factors, VC funding has been consistently growing in India," said Ben Mathias, a managing partner at Vertex Ventures Southeast Asia & India.

Besides funding, domestic developments have encouraged founders and VCs too, Mathias said.

The Indian government's Universal Payment Interface system has spurred consumers and businesses to pay online, and 40% of all digital payments globally happen in India today, the partner said.

Programs like Startup India, which provides founders benefits like tax exemption, easier compliance, and funding support, have made creating a company smoother.

Advertisement

Devyani Parameshwar worked in the microfinance and fintech space in India in the 2010s before heading to the UK and Africa. She returned to India in 2022 to launch a financial management venture.

"It's changed dramatically. I remember standing in line at various ministries in Delhi trying to get meetings and then trying to get answers and it wasn't easy in the past," she said of her memories of India.

Now, she can use an online platform to ask the country's central bank and banking regulator questions.

It's easier than ever for foreign companies to invest in India, which means startups have a clearer exit path through acquisition — something VCs think hard about before entering new markets or writing checks.

Advertisement

Market ripe for the taking

For Rohan Bhide, who spent most of his college and professional life preparing to launch something of his own, a trip home in 2017 while he was studying in the US was a turning point.

Indian telecom giant Reliance had recently launched a cheap unlimited data plan, which spiked Indian internet adoption. India was charting among the countries with the highest online transactions.

"That really, really drew my attention," said Bhide, who worked at Meta after graduation. "It was my dream come true — a huge market, a huge user base, and at the same time, the ability to adopt technology was incredible."

Bhide returned to India in January, leaving behind about $580,000 in total compensation at ticketing platform StubHub. He and a cofounder are working on launching a consumer tech product later this year.

Advertisement

Rohan Bhide returned to India in January after working at Meta and StubHub in the US. Rohan Bhide

Most Indians grew up wanting to work at a multinational company — but that's changing, Bhide said.

Related stories

Freelancing, running your own business, or working for a startup is much more socially acceptable now, because people see the success of other Indian startups. The country has the third-largest number of "unicorns" — companies worth $1 billion or more — with 64, per PitchBook.

Boom in entrepreneurship culture

A lot has changed since Hassan first wanted to launch his hardware startup in the early 2000s.

Tech hot spots like Bengaluru and Gurugram have seen a boom in entrepreneurship culture in the last few years, with meet-ups, networking mixers, and even morning walks with like-minded builders.

Advertisement

Dhruv Anand launched an AI services startup after moving back to India. Dhruv Anand

Dhruv Anand, who left Google in the US to move back to India in 2021 to launch an AI startup, said that there were lots of other founders and mentors to help guide him.

"If you want to figure out who's the right chartered accountant to talk to, who's the right lawyer to help you draft agreements, all of that stuff is very easy," Anand said.

"It's been a really, really supportive community," Bhide said. There are people "telling you about their entire lives just because they want to help you and they're hoping that you pass the favor onto the next person who moves to India and wants to start their own company."

Not everything is perfect

Although these founders made the decision to return to India, that doesn't mean they no longer see the benefits of operating in the US.

Advertisement

Ruchit Garg founded an agriculture startup in Silicon Valley in 2016, with a focus on supporting farmers around the globe. In 2019, he returned to India, where his late grandfather worked as a farmer.

Garg has been building in India ever since, but he says its startup ecosystem cannot yet compete with the Valley's decades of experience.

"The overall ecosystem was more mature back in Silicon Valley. It's still one of the best places for entrepreneurs. India isn't there yet, although it's growing pretty drastically," he said.

Despite efforts to digitalize key processes, many bureaucratic challenges persist.

Advertisement

For most founders, after living in US cities where populations are a fraction of those in Mumbai and Bangalore, congested roads and poorer air quality are also everyday annoyances.

But India provides some big perks, including affordable domestic help and the appeal of building solutions for problems they witness firsthand.

"It's a different joy to be able to build for problems that you feel for very personally," Parameshwar, the fintech founder, said. When she worked in Africa, she needed translators. Now, she can speak with her users herself.

Bhide said the general sentiment among local founders is shifting from "Build from India" to "Build for India."

Advertisement

For some founders, being surrounded by family and the culture they grew up in was another selling point.

Niranjan Vemulkar moved back to India in 2015 and later founded a digital legacy planning platform.

He said that he never fully felt at home in the US, where he lived for over a decade.

"For us, it was the fact that we wanted to raise a family in an environment where the children would have access to the grandparents and Indian culture," Vemulkar said. "The fact that you could come back to India, start something of your own and figure things out in an ecosystem which was potentially booming for startups, was just a cherry on the cake."

Advertisement

Are you in India and have a story to share about the tech and entrepreneurship landscape? Please reach out at shubhangigoel@insider.com

title: Deciphering Progress Software (PRGS) International Revenue Trends
description: Examine the evolution of Progress Software's (PRGS) overseas revenue trends and their effects on Wall Street's forecasts and the stock's prospects.
article_content:
Have you evaluated the performance of Progress Software's (PRGS) international operations for the quarter ending August 2024? Given the extensive global presence of this business software maker, analyzing the patterns in international revenues is crucial for understanding its financial strength and potential for growth.

In the current global economy, which is more interconnected than ever, a company's success in penetrating international markets is crucial for its financial health and growth journey. Investors must understand a company's dependence on overseas markets, as this offers a window into the company's earnings stability, its ability to benefit from varied economic cycles and its potential for long-term growth.

Being present in foreign markets serves as protection against local economic declines and helps benefit from more rapidly expanding economies. Yet, such expansion also introduces challenges related to currency fluctuations, geopolitical uncertainties and varied market behaviors.

While delving into PRGS' performance for the past quarter, we observed some fascinating trends in the revenue from its foreign segments that are commonly modeled and observed by analysts on Wall Street.

For the quarter, the company's total revenue amounted to $178.69 million, experiencing an increase of 1.7% year over year. Next, we'll explore the breakdown of PRGS' international revenue to understand the importance of its overseas business operations.

Exploring PRGS' International Revenue Patterns

During the quarter, Latin America contributed $5.36 million in revenue, making up 3.0% of the total revenue. When compared to the consensus estimate of $4.63 million, this meant a surprise of +15.83%. Looking back, Latin America contributed $4.6 million, or 2.6%, in the previous quarter, and $6.32 million, or 3.6%, in the same quarter of the previous year.

Of the total revenue, $57.03 million came from Europe, Middle East and Africa during the last fiscal quarter, accounting for 31.9%. This represented a surprise of -1.48% as analysts had expected the region to contribute $57.89 million to the total revenue. In comparison, the region contributed $57.54 million, or 32.9%, and $56.78 million, or 32.3%, to total revenue in the previous and year-ago quarters, respectively.

Asia Pacific accounted for 6.7% of the company's total revenue during the quarter, translating to $11.92 million. Revenues from this region represented a surprise of +18.05%, with Wall Street analysts collectively expecting $10.1 million. When compared to the preceding quarter and the same quarter in the previous year, Asia Pacific contributed $10.04 million (5.7%) and $9.97 million (5.7%) to the total revenue, respectively.

Story continues

International Revenue Predictions

The current fiscal quarter's total revenue for Progress Software, as projected by Wall Street analysts, is expected to reach $211.89 million, reflecting an increase of 19.4% from the same quarter last year. The breakdown of this revenue by foreign region is as follows: Latin America is anticipated to contribute 2.4% or $5.11 million, Europe, Middle East and Africa 30.2% or $63.88 million and Asia Pacific 5.3% or $11.15 million.

For the entire year, the company's total revenue is forecasted to be $750.35 million, which is an improvement of 7.5% from the previous year. The revenue contributions from different regions are expected as follows: Latin America will contribute 2.5% ($19 million), Europe, Middle East and Africa 32.3% ($242.39 million) and Asia Pacific 5.5% ($40.93 million) to the total revenue.

Concluding Remarks

Progress Software's leaning on foreign markets for its revenue stream presents a mix of chances and challenges. Therefore, a vigilant watch on its international revenue movements can greatly aid in projecting the company's future direction.

In a world where international interdependencies and geopolitical conflicts are ever-increasing, Wall Street analysts closely monitor these trends for companies having international presence to adjust their earnings forecasts. Of course, there are several other factors, including a company's standing within its home borders, that influence analysts' earnings forecasts.

Here at Zacks, we put a great deal of emphasis on a company's changing earnings outlook, as empirical research has shown that's a powerful force driving a stock's near-term price performance. Quite naturally, the correlation is positive here -- an upward revision in earnings estimates drives the stock price higher.

Boasting a remarkable track record that's been externally verified, the Zacks Rank, our unique stock rating system, leverages changes in earnings projections to function as a reliable gauge for predicting short-term stock price movements.

Progress Software currently has a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy), indicating that it could outperform the broader market in the near term. You can see the complete list of today's Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) stocks here >>>>

Exploring Recent Trends in Progress Software's Stock Price

The stock has increased by 14% over the past month compared to the 2.1% rise of the Zacks S&P 500 composite. Meanwhile, the Zacks Computer and Technology sector, which includes Progress Software, has increased 1.8% during this time frame. Over the past three months, the company's shares have experienced a gain of 20.4% relative to the S&P 500's 4.9% increase. Throughout this period, the sector overall has witnessed a 1% decrease.

title: 8 project management trends for SMBs in 2024
description: Explore the top project management trends for small businesses. Learn how AI, resource management, and cybersecurity can ...
article_content:
Explore the top project management trends for small businesses. Learn how AI, resource management, and cybersecurity can improve project outcomes. Maskot/Getty Images

Whether it's a new dance on TikTok or a technological breakthrough, trends are a core part of daily life, and the project management landscape is no different. Understanding current trends in project management can influence goals and inspire action — which could lead to bigger and better outcomes for your business.

Knowing the latest project management trends can help you plan better, stay ahead of the competition, overcome common project management challenges, and develop your team efficiently. To that end, we've gathered eight project management trends for 2024 specifically tailored for small businesses.

1. Leveraging artificial intelligence (AI)

Artificial intelligence is the single most significant current trend in project management.

“AI can suggest how to break down tasks into more manageable chunks, and those results can be discussed with the project team,” says Craig Guarraci, founder of Tech PM Career Path, LLC, a career coaching company. He adds that “AI can be used to take meeting notes, determine action items, and to send the notes to attendees, thus freeing up the project manager's time.”

From using generative AI to speed up project planning to leveraging AI's automation capabilities to handle repetitive or menial tasks, businesses are relying more and more on the power of large language models (LLMs) and machine learning to improve project outcomes and reach broader business goals.

Through AI, businesses can also determine what projects they should undertake and learn what other organizations are doing to stay ahead.

“AI could be used by a project manager to brainstorm nearly anything about the project and learn about similar projects,” says Guarraci

2. Putting outcomes over inputs

Especially with growth projects, project managers and businesses are placing a stronger emphasis on the tangible outcomes of projects than the amount of work that goes in. By focusing on outcomes, projects align more with business goals, and project managers can more easily define success.

A key way to focus on project outcomes is through change management — both handling changes throughout a project carefully and efficiently and being mindful of organizational changes a project can cause.

“It's great to complete a project on time, on budget, and within scope, but it's even greater to address change throughout the project lifecycle to ensure [the] realization of benefits,” says Nicole Pietrangelo, project management consultant. “After all, that's the real reason why we're doing projects.”

Project managers and business owners can also pivot toward putting outcomes over inputs by:

Shifting success metrics to highlight deliverables instead of the time spent on a task or the number of tasks completed

Using agile methodologies to keep projects transparent and focused on goals

Working backward from desired long-term goals when planning projects rather than starting from short-term needs or capabilities

3. Hybrid and remote workspaces

Remote and hybrid work arrangements are a major trend in project management and employment, partially due to changes made during the global COVID-19 pandemic.

Many employees and employers have found ways to make remote or hybrid work a cost-saving benefit that also improves some workers' work-life balance and overall happiness. Additionally, Upwork's Future of Remote Work study found that one-third of hiring managers say productivity has increased with remote working.

However, hybrid and remote workspaces create a specific challenge for project management: it’s difficult to communicate and collaborate with your team when they’re spread across the globe.

“Something to be aware of, especially in remote work, is the importance and impact of emotional intelligence and understanding that different people communicate differently,” says Bill Morris IV, Director of Project Management at Morris, a custom thermal solutions company. “As an example, this may mean picking up the phone and calling someone instead of sending a quick email, even if the latter may seem quicker and easier.”

Project management programs and software have responded to this challenge by making communication and collaboration within the program more efficient. Other tools and cloud-based project management software, such as Microsoft Teams, Google Drive, Dropbox, Asana, Monday, and Slack, make asynchronous work more attainable and seamless.

4. Bigger reliance on data

Businesses are turning towards data to drive decision-making at all levels to achieve bigger goals. By using data, outcomes can be better predicted, anomalies can be defined, and failures can be used as tools to achieve greater success in the future.

A key trend in project management is making data-driven decisions from the beginning stages of project planning.

“Data-driven decision-making is very important,” says Joe Bowab, CEO and founder of Lobster Anywhere. “It can help improve efficiency and can help make vital decisions regarding the progress of the project.”

Some of the ways project managers can utilize data more effectively in their projects include:

Basing project success on data-driven metrics

Monitoring data points throughout a project to ensure things are on track

Using historical data to inform decisions

5. Increased focus on cybersecurity

Increasing cybersecurity measures may seem like just an IT project management trend, but cybersecurity attacks can affect every area of a business. Striking a balance between safety and efficiency is a challenging line to toe, but it’s vital for companies to keep their employees and data safe from cyberattacks.

Some ways businesses are improving their cybersecurity in project management include:

Establishing role-based permissions to data and programs

Holding periodic cybersecurity training sessions

Having dedicated cybersecurity experts on staff to review projects and ensure there aren’t any holes

6. Prioritizing environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices

Businesses are becoming ever more mindful of ways to minimize their impact on the environment and local communities. As businesses shift toward more sustainable practices, project managers must prioritize ESG practices throughout the project life cycle.

Additionally, business leaders may be relying on project managers to see through environmentally conscious initiatives, especially in areas like infrastructure and energy.

Some ways to keep ESG at the heart of project management are:

Analyzing the environmental impact of project practices and sourcing greener options when possible

Finding ways to make projects benefit local communities and society as a whole in addition to meeting strategic business goals

Crafting ethical standards for projects and meeting local, state, and federal regulatory requirements

7. Being mindful of resource scarcity

With the ever-changing and uncertain economic environment, it’s imperative for companies of all sizes, especially small businesses, to look for ways to stay competitive while staying mindful of their resources. Project managers have to find ways to do more with less, which requires getting creative with project planning and resourcing.

Some ways for businesses to hop on the trend of being mindful of resources include:

Adopting agile methodologies to keep projects efficient

Leveraging technology, like software and AI, to streamline tasks and automate some project aspects

Utilize free project management software and freelance work to minimize project expenses (Try Monday, HubSpot, or ClickUp for free.)

Get stakeholders involved to capitalize on their knowledge and outside perspective

8. Increasing communication and transparency

Project managers have always walked a tight line between transparency and security. On the one hand, keeping a project under tight wraps can prevent information leaks, and having strict silos may allow employees to focus better on their tasks.

However, building a more transparent project environment where communication is encouraged can help introduce new ideas, build a stronger sense of connection to work for team members, and mitigate confusion, especially in large-scale projects. As many teams shift toward agile methodologies, communication is key.

Beyond the rapid technological advancements in project management, managers also must “become expert problem-solvers, critical thinkers, communicators, and leaders,” says Pietrangelo. “While technological advancements lead to new processes and ways of working, project managers need to understand how to guide their teams through change and establish trust during uncertain times.”

Some ways to consider improving your project team’s communication and transparency include:

Utilizing asynchronous communication methods, like Slack or Microsoft Teams

Giving frequent updates on project progress

Promoting cross-team collaboration on projects

Bottom line: Understanding trends in project management

In 2024, staying ahead of the curve means embracing project management trends like leveraging AI, making data-driven decisions, and prioritizing ESG practices. Ensuring your business is flexible and adaptable to the ebbs and flows of the project management landscape is crucial for ensuring your projects meet business goals and deliver meaningful results.

Frequently asked questions

What are the latest trends in project management?

Some of the latest trends in project management include integrating artificial intelligence (AI) into project processes and relying on data to drive decisions. Other trends, like doing more with fewer resources and staying mindful of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices, are crucial for many project management teams.

What are the future trends in project management?

Future trends in project management will rely heavily on technological advances. As AI becomes more broadly integrated, new ways to leverage it for project management are inevitable. Additionally, the environmental impact of projects will continue to be a priority for many businesses, and brainstorming project ideas that can improve how businesses impact and interact with the environment will only become more necessary as climate change evolves.

What are some types of project management?
